sn7.11:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.
sn7.11:4.3: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed five hundred ploughs, it being the season for sowing.
sn7.11:4.4: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.
sn7.11:5.1: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.
sn7.11:5.2: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place
sn7.11:5.4: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms
sn7.11:5.6: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.
sn7.11:5.7: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”
sn7.11:5.8: “I too plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.”
sn7.11:5.9: “I don’t see Master Gotama with a yoke or plough or ploughshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:
sn7.11:5.10: ‘I too plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.’”
sn7.11:5.11: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn7.11:6.2: but I don’t see your plough.
sn7.11:6.3: If you’re a farmer, declare to me:
sn7.11:6.4: how are we to understand your farming?”
sn7.11:7.1: “Faith is my seed, austerity my rain,
sn7.11:7.2: and wisdom is my yoke and plough.
sn7.11:7.3: Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,
sn7.11:8.2: I restrict my intake of food.
sn7.11:8.3: I use truth as my scythe,
sn7.11:9.1: Energy is my beast of burden,
sn7.11:9.2: transporting me to a place of sanctuary.
sn7.11:9.4: to the place where there is no sorrow.
sn7.11:10.1: That’s how to do the farming
sn7.11:10.2: that has the Deathless as its fruit.
sn7.11:11.3: For Master Gotama does the farming that has the Deathless as its fruit.”
sn7.11:12.1: “Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat.
sn7.11:12.2: That’s not the way of those who see, brahmin.
sn7.11:12.3: The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells.
sn7.11:12.4: Since nature is real, brahmin, that’s how they live.
sn7.11:13.1: Serve with other food and drink
sn7.11:13.2: the consummate one, the great seer,
sn7.11:13.3: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.
sn7.11:13.4: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”
sn7.11:14.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer said to the Buddha:
sn7.11:14.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
